title: Girl, Woman, Other
description: Tracking the lives and loves of a dozen British women through generations and social classes, Girl, Woman, Other weaves a distinctive, illuminating tapestry of modern British life.
author: Bernardine Evaristo

title: The Truants
description: A compelling, character driven thriller set on a breezeblock university campus, The Truants is a very modern coming-of-age tale. Incorporating issues of belonging and toxic friendships within a fast-moving, wire-taut narrative, Weinberg’s impressive debut carries echoes of The Secret History whilst very much retaining its own identity.
author: Kate Weinberg

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
description: A remarkable debut bubbles over with the melting-pot tension of a community beset by tragedy and shaped by the landscape that surrounds it. Character-driven, with an impeccable sense of place and time, this is a richly imagined story of innocence undone and of a small town torn and re-shaped by crisis.
author: Delia Owens

title: Normal People
description: Capturing the zeitgeist with all the skill and subtlety of her debut, Conversations with Friends, Sally Rooney’s Normal People follows the intersecting story of Marianne and Connell as they navigate the changing landscape of their relationship into adulthood. Deftly written, emotionally honest and devastatingly perceptive, Normal People is an award-winning modern classic.
author: Sally Rooney

title: The Beekeeper of Aleppo
description: Moving, powerful, compassionate and beautifully written, The Beekeeper of Aleppo is a testament to the triumph of the human spirit. Told with deceptive simplicity, it is the kind of book that reminds us of the power of storytelling
author: Christy Lefteri

title: Little Fires Everywhere
description: Discover the novel that everybody is talking about. Now a hugely successful Hulu miniseries starring and produced by Reese Witherspoon and Kerry Washington, Celeste Ng’s incendiary work is a breathless thriller that demands to be read.
author: Celeste Ng

title: Conversations with Friends
description: Two couples relationships become messily entangled in this mordantly funny debut that established Rooney as the formidable new voice of a generation.
author: Sally Rooney

title: Heaven, My Home - Highway 59
description: From the author of Bluebird,Bluebird, Heaven, My Home sees the second outing for Ranger Darren Matthews. In the wake of Trump’s election, he must solve a terrible crime whilst battling a new wave of racial violence that rises amidst the enduring prejudices in the Deep South. As well as a twisty, fast-paced thriller, Heaven, My Home is a powerful, angry portrait of today’s America.
author: Attica Locke

title: The Long Call - Two Rivers
description: The first in a new Devon-set crime series from the accomplished creator of the Shetland and Vera novels, The Long Call sees a troubled detective returning to the community he turned his back on. Plotted with Cleeves’ customary deft skill and introducing a complex, flawed new protagonist, The Long Call bodes very well for this fresh mystery series.
author: Ann Cleeves

title: Machines Like Me
description: Hot on the heels of his screen adaptations of On Chesil Beach and The Children Act, McEwan turns his incisive authorial eye to the brave new world of artificial intelligence. Rewinding the clock on an alternative eighties Britain McEwan delivers a spry and accomplished novel, set in a place where the Beatles have reformed, Tony Benn has swept into office and radical technology spawns a new generation of artificial humans. A story ripe with questions about consciousness, inevitability and the nature of desire.
author: Ian McEwan

title: The Flatshare
description: The will-they won’t-they relationship between two residents of the same flat who happen to have never met forms the basis of this witty and charming gem. Deliciously light and frothy, O’Leary’s wonderfully uplifting debut is a joyous confection of comic misunderstanding and endearing romance.
author: Beth O'Leary

title: The Dutch House: Exclusive Edition
description: Rich in metaphor and flawless in tone, The Dutch House sees one of the world’s finest living novelists at the top of her game. Shimmering with melancholy, this extraordinary book takes a scalpel to family dynamics and the irretrievable loss of youthful pride. A novel of jewel-like beauty and emotional insight.
author: Ann Patchett

title: An American Marriage
description: A tender and humane dissection of what happens to a relationship when unforeseen events conspire to sabotage it. Tayari Jones’ handling of her protagonists’ emotions is a masterclass in authentic characterisation whilst the story subtly probes issues of race and justice with a piercing emotional intelligence and colossal heart.
author: Tayari Jones

title: Tidelands
description: The first of an evocative new series from the Queen of historical fiction, Tidelands is set in a seventeenth-century England caught in the maelstrom of civil war and obsessed with the prevalence of witches. In Alinor, Gregory crafts yet another vibrant, captivating heroine who must learn to survive in a world that is implacably opposed to her very existence.
author: Philippa Gregory

title: The Chain
description: Built upon a premise so simple yet so ingenious, Adrian McKinty takes the reader on a chilling journey into the darkest recesses of the human heart and asks exactly how far you would go to protect the ones you love. A stark, unputdownable standalone thriller from the author of the Detective Sean Duffy series.
author: Adrian McKinty

title: The Doll Factory
description: This darkly atmospheric debut from Elizabeth Macneal is a brooding examination of female subjugation wrapped in the cloak of a rattling good period yarn. In a Victorian London so richly evoked that you can practically taste the fog, the aspiring artist Iris Whittle finds herself caught between the affections of pre-Raphaelite artist Louis Frost and the altogether more unsavoury taxidermist Silas Reed. Alongside her two admirers Iris also has to contend with the festering resentment of her jealous sister and a society which seems determined to keep her in her place. As events move toward their end, repressed desire and obsessive love threaten to destroy everything that Iris holds dear.
author: Elizabeth Macneal

title: Before the Coffee Gets Cold
description: Charmingly written and nimbly translated, Kawaguchi’s life-affirming tale of café-based time travel and symbolic hot beverages has all the hallmarks of a beloved cult classic. Poignant and gently funny, Before the Coffee Gets Cold is a winning fable about regret and reclaiming lost opportunities.
author: Toshikazu Kawaguchi

title: The Secrets We Kept
description: A literary thriller about the forbidden thrill of literature, Prescott’s astonishing debut sees a duo of CIA typists attempt to smuggle Pasternak’s Doctor Zhivago back into Soviet Russia. Wholly original and brilliantly realised, The Secrets We Kept hymns the subversive power of great prose whilst ratcheting up the tension with masterly technique.
author: Lara Prescott

title: Nineteen Eighty-Four - Penguin Modern Classics
description: Orwell’s brilliantly bleak future vision of totalitarianism is arguably the greatest of all literary dystopias. Both in its impeccably realised world-building and the prophetic nature of its many ideological concepts, Nineteen Eighty-Four contrived to look back to the Stalinist purges of the 1930s whilst simultaneously predicting with uncanny accuracy the worst excesses of the Cold War-era Soviet Union. A textbook example of a novel you really must read.
author: George Orwell

title: Once Upon a River
description: Beguiling and multi-faceted, the latest novel from the author of The Thirteenth Tale brings together a winning cast of characters around the meandering Thames, each drawn into a mystery that reopens old wounds and lays to rest unburied ghosts. There’s much to enjoy in Setterfield’s ability to spin a deeply satisfying and richly told story and Once Upon a River contains just the right balance of the sweet and the bitter, along with a clever and satisfying playfulness with the traditions of storytelling itself. It’s a novel that reminds you why we all tell stories and why they continue to matter.
author: Diane Setterfield

title: The Tattooist of Auschwitz
description: A heartfelt tale of love born in darkness, inspired by the astonishing true story of Lale Sokolov, The Tattooist of Auschwitz is as remarkable as it is life-affirming. At times almost unbearably poignant, Morris’ deft approach to the most emotive subject matter is a triumph of empathetic storytelling.
author: Heather Morris

title: Wolf Hall - The Wolf Hall Trilogy
author: Hilary Mantel

title: Daisy Jones and The Six
description: A mesmeric novel of fame, love, music and what happens when luck runs out and the lights go down, Daisy Jones & The Six tells the story of the stratospheric rise of a band whose sound defined an era and whose sudden, cataclysmic split left a trail of unanswered questions in its wake. Intoxicatingly written, with a cast of characters to instantly fall for, it’s a nostalgia-fuelled trip into the heady world of 70's L.A. at its hedonistic peak.
author: Taylor Jenkins Reid

title: Circe
description: Shortlisted for Waterstones Book of the Year 2018. The Song of Achilles’ author unspools a tantalising mythological tale of survival, transformation, revenge and women’s fight to be free.
author: Madeline Miller

title: The King's Evil - James Marwood & Cat Lovett 3
description: The author of the bestselling The Ashes of London and The Fire Court, Andrew Taylor returns with another outing of James Marwood, the son of a traitor, in Restoration London. Marwood faces his most towering challenge yet, as murder and scandal taint the royal court of Charles II. Atmospheric, complex and riveting, The King’s Evil is historical suspense at its finest.
author: Andrew Taylor

title: Girl
description: Girl proves that, even in her 89th year, Edna O’Brien remains one of the greatest living prose stylists. The tale of a girl abducted by Nigerian terrorists, this masterly novel refines O’Brien’s signature concern with the social, sexual and religious oppression of women and speaks keenly to the most relevant issues of modern society.
author: Edna O'Brien

title: The Handmaid's Tale
description: An unforgettable portrait of defiance and authoritarian rule, The Handmaid's Tale is a classic dystopian vision of a terrifyingly believable future. A devastatingly powerful exploration of female oppression with an all-too chilling resonance for our times.
author: Margaret Atwood

title: The Mystery of Henri Pick - Walter Presents
description: An elegant, irresistibly farcical comic mystery based around a library of rejected manuscripts, Foenkinos’s playful satire is the perfect feelgood read. An ideal novel for bibliophiles everywhere, The Mystery of Henri Pick abounds with Gallic wit and charm.
author: David Foenkinos

title: A Gentleman in Moscow: The worldwide bestseller
author: Amor Towles

title: Blood & Sugar
description: The political tinderbox of 1780’s London provides the perfect backdrop for an intriguing and original thriller from Laura Shepherd-Robinson. Spurred on by the discovery of the corpse of a notorious abolitionist on Deptford Dock - mutilated with tell-tale slavers’ marks - an aspiring politician and former soldier sets out on the trail of a murderer and finds much more than he bargained for. As his investigations set him at odds with pro-slavery lobbyists, invested businessmen and even his own wife, so he starts to unearth a scandal that threatens to turn the tide of public opinion – with perilous repercussions. Tightly plotted and impeccably researched, without ever straying into polemic, Blood & Sugar mines a rich historical seam for a thoroughly immersive slice of period mystery.
author: Laura Shepherd-Robinson

title: Middle England
description: Exhuming his coterie of recurring characters, Jonathan Coe unleashes a wry, mercilessly funny novel of modern Britain and the madness of Brexit. Whilst his pen is frequently savagely satirical, Coe is a keen observer of human foibles and there is an empathy and affection for his protagonists here that offsets the darker political content.
author: Jonathan Coe

title: Beloved
description: The seminal work from a giant of modern literature, Beloved is so much more than the sum of its compelling parts. Part ghost story, part profound reflection on the evils of slavery, Morrison’s Pulitzer-winning masterpiece synthesises myriad themes and ideas into a scorching, emotionally devastating narrative.
author: Toni Morrison

title: Mythos: The Greek Myths Retold - Stephen Fry's Greek Myths
description: Dryly funny and packed with crackling, quick-witted dialogue, Mythos gives fresh bite and relevance to age-old legends, proving that, when it comes to storytelling, Fry certainly has the Midas touch.
author: Stephen Fry

title: Sword of Kings: Exclusive Edition - The Last Kingdom Series 12
description: The twelfth book in the Last Kingdom series is every bit as fresh and accomplished as the first. As Uhtred’s character shifts and eddies, the Saxon world that he inhabits is changing too, and there will be profound consequences for all who are too tied to the past.
author: Bernard Cornwell

title: Eleanor Oliphant is Completely Fine
description: The winner of the 2017 Costa Book of the Year is a quietly profound novel that celebrates ordinary acts of kindness and gently compels us to regard others – and even ourselves – a little differently.
author: Gail Honeyman

title: My Brilliant Friend - Neapolitan Quartet
description: Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan novels have become undisputed modern classics famed for their meticulous characterisation and richly evoked atmosphere. Luminously written and expertly translated, My Brilliant Friend begins the epic coming-of-age not just of Elena and Lila but of the Italian nation itself.
author: Elena Ferrante

title: The Nickel Boys: Exclusive Edition
description: Throbbing with righteous anger and visceral prose, The Nickel Boys takes the real-life Florida reform school as a jumping off point to explore the tensions inherent in the US Civil Rights movement. Powerful and incendiary, The Nickel Boys cements Whitehead’s formidable reputation as one of the greatest living American writers.
author: Colson Whitehead

title: Bring Up the Bodies - The Wolf Hall Trilogy
description: The second part in Hilary Mantel’s Booker Prize-winning Wolf Hall Trilogy follows Thomas Cromwell as he finds himself at the heart of Henry’s court. And as Cromwell manoeuvres himself ever-closer to Henry, memories surface and his own plans – long in the making – come to a thrilling and terrifying fruition, for vengeance is a dish best served cold.
author: Hilary Mantel

title: The Silence of the Girls
description: Pat Barker’s electrifying revision of The Iliad reframes the story through the voiceless women of war. A startlingly vivid novel with a powerful message about who tells stories and why it matters.
author: Pat Barker

title: The Plague - Penguin Modern Classics
description: Camus’s masterpiece on the effects of isolation, claustrophobia and moral recklessness in an Algerian village ravaged by the plague weaves an extraordinary tapestry of life governed by fear. Humane, haunting and timeless, The Plague is a chilling, razor-sharp examination of freedom and responsibility.
author: Albert Camus

title: Nine Perfect Strangers
description: Tightly-plotted, impossibly twisty and wickedly funny, the latest page-turner from the creator of Big Little Lies serves up another wildly entertaining ride. Nine stressed out city dwellers descend upon an island paradise to recuperate, little suspecting what sinister goings-on await them there.
author: Liane Moriarty

title: Those People
description: Candlish returns to pull at the tantalising threads of neighbourly harmony, asking how far a community might go to protect their little England. Mirroring the on-tenterhooks, slow-reveal structure of Liane Moriarty’s Big Little Lies and peopled by a brilliant cast of nuanced, believable characters, Those People is a masterclass in tension that probes the darkest corners of everyday prejudice and malice.
author: Louise Candlish

title: Spring - Seasonal Quartet
description: Having captured the chaos and catharsis of the dying embers and slumbering promise of Autumn and Winter in 2017 and 2018, Ali Smith turns to new beginnings for the third novel in her peerless seasonal quartet. Interweaving mythical, ancient and primal ideas about the years’ changing faces with a startling immediacy that is fresh, funny and poignant Spring captures - wholly and ineffably – the moment we are in.
author: Ali Smith

title: The Luminaries
description: A staggering feat of both novelistic structure and relentlessly sustained narrative tension, the Booker Prize winning The Luminaries almost defies categorisation. Set in nineteenth-century gold rush New Zealand it is a period ghost story, labyrinthine crime thriller and immersive character study all rolled into one exquisitely constructed masterwork.
author: Eleanor Catton

title: The Familiars
description: Strikingly evoking the heartland of seventeenth-century industrial Lancashire, Stacey Halls’ accomplished debut is a haunting novel of two women struggling to fight against the expectation and superstition of their age. Told with an infectious passion for the period, Halls’ blend of compelling plot and vividly drawn landscape crafts an unforgettable story of bewitching power.
author: Stacey Halls

title: Heroes: The myths of the Ancient Greek heroes retold - Stephen Fry's Greek Myths
description: Hot on the legend-gilded heels of his triumphant Mythos, Stephen Fry returns for a second collection of matchless retellings of cowardice, courage and sacrifice under the gaze of the gods.
author: Stephen Fry

title: Lanny: Exclusive Edition
description: Fusing the modern with the mythic and the prosaic with the polyphonic, Porter’s spare, spectral novel mines folklore, fable and the deep-dug tendrils of village life for something both age-old and vibrantly alive. Shortlisted for the 2019 Waterstones Book of the Year, Lanny is state-of-the-nation rendered as pagan legend and a poignant paean to childhood, friendship and landscape.
author: Max Porter

title: The Priory of the Orange Tree
description: In a change of pace from her bestselling series The Bone Season, author Samantha Shannon offers up a new standalone high-fantasy epic, led by an impressive cast of memorable female characters. Set in an impeccably realised world of dragons, warring factions and underground rebellion, The Priory of the Orange Tree has all the hallmarks of a fantasy classic.
author: Samantha Shannon

title: Little Women - The Penguin English Library
description: Brimming with life and each sharply delineated, Little Women’s titular sisters continue to influence and inspire a century and a half after Louisa May Alcott created them. A compelling family drama set in the shadow of the American Civil War, Little Women is a triumph of characterisation and deft storytelling.
author: Louisa May Alcott

title: The Underground Railroad
description: A nightmarish evocation of the moral torpor and unthinking brutality of the Antebellum South, Whitehead’s narrative thunders along with the relentless pull and desperate motion of the titular subterranean boxcar system that transported slaves across the United States. Furious, wise and unbearably poignant, The Underground Railroad stands as Whitehead’s supreme achievement.
author: Colson Whitehead

title: Find Me
description: Aciman’s languorous Call Me by Your Name became a worldwide bestseller and this highly anticipated sequel promises to follow suit. Skilfully replicating the sensuous atmosphere and hypnotic romance of its predecessor, Find Me sings with wistful beauty and tender longing.
author: Andre Aciman

title: The Fire Next Time - Penguin Modern Classics
description: Immensely influential and profoundly moving, Baldwin’s twin letters on his childhood in Harlem and the omnipresent evil of racism in American society were pivotal in the galvanising of the US civil rights movement. Unfailingly eloquent and brimming with passion and heartache, The Fire Next Time frames the battles of the 1960s in an urgent and ever more relevant context for the modern era.
author: James Baldwin

title: To Kill A Mockingbird
description: A true American classic and a novel whose crusading spirit and memorable characters have passed into literary folklore, To Kill a Mockingbird views the brutality of racism in the Deep South through the eyes of child narrator, Scout. Immensely affecting and exquisitely written, Lee’s iconic work retains every ounce of its remarkable power into the twenty-first century.
author: Harper Lee

title: The Parisian
description: Arriving on a torrent of critical acclaim, including a glowing recommendation from Zadie Smith, Isabella Hammad’s debut is an ambitious and superbly realised historical epic. Part love story, part social drama it moves from Palestine to Montpellier and Paris during a turbulent period from the end of the Ottoman Empire to the outbreak of the Second World War. Beautifully – tenderly – written, it’s a story that sings in its depiction of real lives caught up in history’s undertow.
author: Isabella Hammad

title: The Shadow of the Wind - The Cemetery of Forgotten Books 1
author: Carlos Ruiz Zafon

title: Late in the Day
description: Neatly navigating the ebbs and flows of the relationship between two couples as they weather the impact of a sudden tragedy on the ecosystem of their lives, Tessa Hadley has created a superbly nuanced portrait of friendship and marriage. Echoing the quiet, penetrating observation of Anita Brookner, Hadley writes with subtlety and great skill about the interplay between society, class, history and the passions that shape our everyday experience.
author: Tessa Hadley

title: All the Light We Cannot See
description: One of the towering achievements of twenty-first century literature, All the Light We Cannot See paints a transcendent picture of love and companionship during the Nazi occupation of France. Through luminous prose and dextrous characterisation, Doerr crafts a modern epic and a sublime story for the ages.
author: Anthony Doerr

title: The Offing
description: From the author of the brutally brilliant The Gallows Pole comes an altogether different kind of historical novel. Set during the aftermath of the Second World War, The Offing recounts a tender story of love and friendship between a teenage miner and an eccentric older woman, with all the immersive detail and fulsome characterisation of Myers’ previous work.
author: Benjamin Myers

title: How We Disappeared
description: How We Disappeared is a haunting, visceral and profound meditation on trauma, memory and forgiveness. The novel’s dual narrative moves between contemporary Singapore and the 1942 Japanese invasion, weaving together two timelines, two life-altering secrets and two people who come together in their search for reconciliation with the past.
author: Jing-Jing Lee

title: The Sleepwalker - Aidan Waits
description: The third installment in this exciting and atmospheric crime series really gets under the skin of maverick detective Aidan Waits, with a descent into nightmarish noir courtesy of an expiring serial killer. Knox does hard-boiled with a scintillating modern slant that hooks the reader from the first page.
author: Joseph Knox

title: A Village Scandal - The Village Secrets 2
author: Dilly Court

title: The Secret History: From the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Goldfinch
author: Donna Tartt

title: Tombland - The Shardlake series
description: Vividly imagining 16th-century England, Sansom’s peerless Shardlake series continues with a captivating mystery that threatens not only court and country, but those Matthew himself holds most dear. Another magnificent addition to one of the most accomplished crime series’ out there.
author: C. J. Sansom

title: The Mobster's Lament - City Blues Quartet
description: Riveting and ambitious, the third part of Ray Celestin’s atmospheric City Blues Quartet continues the story of Gabriel Leveson – a gangster trying to break free from his association with one of New York’s leading mafia families. An irresistible, multi-layered piece of neo-noir crime fiction, filled with unforgettable characters and old-world charm.
author: Ray Celestin

title: Brave New World: Special 3D Edition
description: A classic sci-fi dystopia that started out as a parody of H.G. Wells’s Utopian novels, Brave New World is a savage critique of the fallacy of the perfect state, the vogue for genetic engineering and the idea of the noble savage. Brimming with satirical concepts that have been borne out by the passage of time, Huxley’s masterpiece is as relevant now as it ever has been.
author: Aldous Huxley

title: Ordinary People
description: The drama of the everyday is at the heart of Diana Evans vibrant third novel. Opening on the night of Barack Obama’s inauguration, Ordinary People captures the lives of two couples, navigating the landscape of black and mixed-race middle class domesticity, parenthood and the unravelling confines of the settled-for life. Evans prose is sparklingly light on its feet and brings pathos and humour to an insightful examination of modern life so filmic it even has its own soundtrack. As the Guardian says, Ordinary People is an accomplished novel, brought to life by ‘the sheer energy and effervescence of Evans’s funny, sad, magnificent prose.’
author: Diana Evans

title: The October Man: A Rivers of London Novella
description: Having reached the seventh instalment of his urban fantasy series, The Rivers of London, Ben Aaronovitch gives Peter Grant a much-needed break as he explores the world of magic beyond England’s confines. Set in Trier, Germany, The October Man transports his cocktail mix of real observation and brilliant imagination to an inviting new locale, throwing in a cast of colourful new characters for good measure.
author: Ben Aaronovitch

title: The Rosie Result - The Rosie Project Series
description: Graham Simsion’s much-loved trilogy – begun with The Rosie Project and continued in The Rosie Effect – is concluded with aplomb in this richly funny and warm-hearted final novel. Simsion brings real depth and conviction to his central protagonists, whilst exploring – more overtly than in previous novels – questions about autism and identity. Readers who have grown to love Don and Rosie will be pleased they’ve followed their story to its hopeful and rewarding conclusion.
author: Graeme Simsion

title: Milkman
description: Anna Burns’ blistering Orwell and Man Booker Prize-winning novel displaces the Northern Irish troubles to a nameless city populated by anonymous citizens. The power games and creeping psychopathy of Milkman’s central relationship expertly echo the toxic atmosphere and fanaticism of bullet-riddled Belfast, succeeding in making the novel a powerful political statement as well as a brilliantly disquieting study of ruinous obsession.
author: Anna Burns

title: Small Island
description: A masterful, humane account of the experience of the Windrush generation, and a vivid portrait of post-war London, its inhabitants and their conflicts. An important, thought-provoking book written by an author whose knack for characterisation was unparalleled.
author: Andrea Levy

title: Island on the Edge of the World
author: Deborah Rodriguez

title: Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead
description: Olga Tokarczuk turns from the roving, travelling kaleidoscope of Flights to a fabulous, ecological neo-noir. Mike, manager of our Bridport shop, neatly describes the novel as ‘a book that is in every way not bland’, the tale’s central character of Janina Duszejko emerging as a heroic, beautifully-nuanced maelstrom of compassion, fury and almost cosmic insight.
author: Olga Tokarczuk

title: Paris Echo
description: Many novels romanticise the City of Light but few really get to grips with the guilt and shame of some of its recent history. In Paris Echo the typically astute and perceptive Sebastian Faulks does exactly that, crafting a compelling tale of discovery and identity haunted by the ghosts of occupation and colonial war.
author: Sebastian Faulks

title: The Overstory
description: A story of a vast, unknown and interconnected world above the one we know, Richard Powers' thirteenth book brings together the lives of strangers, each summoned by trees. Arching from antebellum New York to late twentieth-century Pacific Northwest, it is a glorious, ambitious novel of how we can learn to recognise a history and pattern to the world beyond our own. Through an epic series of tales, separated by location and time, we rediscover our lost interrelationship with the vast and magisterial sentience of trees, and in the process we find our redemption.
author: Richard Powers

title: Out of Love
description: Hayes’s touching, bittersweet, and ultimately optimistic debut, Out of Love deconstructs a relationship, moving backwards from the breakup to the magical start.  Beautifully lucid, raw and unflinching, this autopsy of a broken heart feels at once completely unique and universal.
author: Hazel Hayes

title: Black Leopard, Red Wolf: Dark Star Trilogy Book 1 - Dark Star Trilogy
author: Marlon James

title: Rebecca - Virago Modern Classics
description: From the exclusive beaches of Monte Carlo to the verdant grounds of Maxim de Winter’s stately home Manderley, Daphne du Maurier’s gothic classic transports the reader into a social and psychological world of creeping menace and dark desires. Rebecca endures as du Maurier’s masterpiece and Mrs Danvers, the superbly sinister housekeeper, stands as a fictional icon.
author: Daphne Du Maurier

title: Killing Commendatore
description: The epic new novel from Haruki Murakami, the internationally acclaimed and best-selling author of 1Q84. A tour de force of love and loneliness, war and art - as well as a loving homage to The Great Gatsby - Killing Commendatore is a stunning work of imagination from one of our greatest writers.
author: Haruki Murakami

title: Of Mice and Men - Penguin Modern Classics
author: John Steinbeck

title: Wakenhyrst
description: The brooding, pervasive aura of the Suffolk fens permeates every nook and cranny of Michelle Paver’s grippingly gothic historic tale of madness, witchcraft and family enmity. Paver proves herself adept in drawing out both the enthralling beauty and the dangerous potential of an uncanny landscape, using it to tease out the fear and malevolence in the lives of those it touches.
author: Michelle Paver

title: Everything I Never Told You
description: A blistering study in grief and belonging that doubles as a gripping mystery of secrets buried in plain sight, this debut ripples with emotion and insight. A novel of difference, the immigrant experience and the changing face of American society; an exquisitely realised work.
author: Celeste Ng

title: The Two Lives of Lydia Bird
description: A gorgeous, emotional read ideal for fans of Jojo Moyes and Paige Toon, The Two Lives of Lydia Bird sings with compassion and warmth. The story of a woman caught between personal tragedy and the chance to remake the past, Josie Silver’s novel is perfect for cuddling up with.
author: Josie Silver

title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child - Parts One and Two: The Official Playscript of the Original West End Production
author: J. K. Rowling

title: Unsheltered
description: Kingsolver’s work is rooted in the way human lives intersect with a world at risk. Her latest novel is no exception: a story of shifting global perspective, seen by the light cast by past generations.
author: Barbara Kingsolver

title: Things in Jars
description: With her first novels, Jess Kidd established a distinctive and playful gothic tone that won over a host of Waterstones’ booksellers. There’s equal enjoyment to be found in her latest offering. A Victorian mystery, generously laced with uncanny twists and sideways glances, Things in Jars moves at a lick, and with surprises and vaudeville treats aplenty, it’s a treat.
author: Jess Kidd

title: Transcription
description: From a beguiling cast of charlatans and spies, Atkinson builds a labyrinthine plot that dazzles even as it leads you deeper into the fog. Enthralling, witty and worldly-wise fiction.
author: Kate Atkinson

title: Traitors of Rome (Eagles of the Empire 18): Roman army heroes Cato and Macro face treachery in the ranks
description: The blood, sweat and intrigue of Ancient Rome brought to life by a master of historical fiction. Chapter eighteen in the bestselling Eagles of the Empire series finds Cato and Macro amidst Parthian spies and battling an unknown enemy within. Rich in Scarrow’s attention to detail and precise world-building, Traitors of Rome is a heart-pounding read.
author: Simon Scarrow

title: A Book of Bones - Charlie Parker Thriller 17
author: John Connolly

title: The Haunted Hotel & Other Stories - Tales of Mystery & The Supernatural
author: Wilkie Collins

title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
description: In the captivating penultimate part of J.K. Rowling’s world-renowned series, the times are a-changing at Hogwarts: the newly-appointed potion-master seems to keep a few too many secrets, and Dumbledore has a clandestine mission in store for Harry. There is a traitor at the very heart of the school and the truth about the identity of the Half-Blood prince is waiting to be discovered.
author: J. K. Rowling

title: Under Occupation
description: The reigning king of the wartime spy novel, Alan Furst delivers another superior slice of espionage set in occupied Paris. Steeped in intrigue and paranoia, Under Occupation invokes resistance safe houses and top secret documents in a thrilling journey into the heart of enemy territory.
author: Alan Furst

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
description: In this magnificent final installment of J. K. Rowling’s masterpiece, Harry, Ron and Hermione must face their biggest challenges yet, and even the strongest friendships are tested to their limit in the face of loss and misfortune. As Harry’s seventeenth birthday approaches, it is time for him to face Voldemort alone in one final, deadly duel. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is an enchanting, heart-breaking conclusion to the epic series.
author: J. K. Rowling

title: Pride and Prejudice
description: Austen’s most famous novel, the delightfully witty courtship of Elizabeth Bennet and Fitzwilliam Darcy is brimming with character, playfulness and irony. Impeccably crafted in flawless prose, Pride and Prejudice remains one of the jewels in the crown of English literature.
author: Jane Austen

title: The Seven Sisters - The Seven Sisters
author: Lucinda Riley

title: Pachinko
description: Boasting a remarkably accomplished epic sweep and sharply focused attention to character and place, Min Jin Lee’s breathtaking saga chronicles the lives of four generations of Japanese citizens with rich psychological acuity. With profound things to say about dislocation and national identity, Pachinko’s deft prose beguiles and entices throughout.
author: Min Jin Lee

title: Frankissstein: A Love Story
description: Form very much reflects subject matter in Jeanette Winterson’s astonishing new novel, as the celebrated author of Oranges are Not the Only Fruit splices together the iconic narrative of Frankenstein with a modern day dissection of AI, cryogenics and synthetic humanity. As any Winterson reader might expect, there’s plenty of wry, tongue-in-cheek, black humour to her lively and energetic reanimation of Mary Shelley’s man-made monster novel. The result is a magnificently macabre fable about body image and body horror that encompasses some of the most contentious and pertinent issues of the day.
author: Jeanette Winterson

title: Half of a Yellow Sun - 4th Estate Matchbook Classics
description: Set against the brutal backdrop of the Nigerian Civil War, Adichie’s soaring epic entwines three deftly drawn characters in a web of faded colonialism, racial antagonism and vexed romance. Conjuring a richly evocative image of a complex, violent West Africa, Half of a Yellow Sun is a magnificently accomplished and emotionally engaging novel.
author: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie

title: Lethal White: Cormoran Strike Book 4
description: After the tumultuous cliffhanger ending of Career of Evil, Lethal White sees Cormoran Strike and Robin Ellacott face professional and personal demons in a series that goes from strength to strength.
author: Robert Galbraith

title: The Great Gatsby - Penguin Modern Classics
description: One of the undisputed jewels of American fiction, Fitzgerald’s dazzling critique of the superficiality of the Jazz Age continues to exert a seismic influence on contemporary literature. Capturing the glamorous facade at the heart of the American Dream in devastating style, The Great Gatsby is a masterpiece of penetrating concision.
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

title: The Fifth Season - Broken Earth Trilogy 1
description: Jemisin’s The Broken Earth trilogy is one of the most acclaimed fantasy sequences of recent years and The Fifth Season is where it all begins. A bravura example of literary world-building and rich, rounded characterisation, this is a novel that will still be being read in fifty years-time.
author: N. K. Jemisin

title: Heartburn - Virago Modern Classics
description: Ephron’s own marital woes fuel this acidly hilarious novel about a cookery writer’s romantic misadventures. Sprinkled liberally with both delicious recipes and one-liners, Heartburn is a marvel of precision engineered prose and biting, satirical characterisation.
author: Nora Ephron

title: Mr Loverman
description: Quietly trailblazing in its depiction of homosexuality in Britain’s elder Caribbean community, Evaristo’s sparkling, nuanced novel revolves around Barrington Walker and his struggle to admit his sexuality to his friends and loved ones. Compassionate and vibrant, Mr Loverman sings with humanity and the need to be true to your innermost feelings.
author: Bernardine Evaristo

title: The Girl Who Lived Twice
description: Scintillatingly structured and cast in the kind of whip-smart prose that made the original trilogy so compelling, David Lagercrantz’s third contribution to Stieg Larsson’s Millennium series may well be his most gripping yet.
author: David Lagercrantz

title: The Ashes of London - James Marwood & Cat Lovett 1
author: Andrew Taylor

title: Six Tudor Queens: Anna of Kleve, Queen of Secrets: Six Tudor Queens 4
author: Alison Weir

title: If I Had Your Face: Signed Edition
author: Frances Cha

title: Conviction
description: Skilfully exploiting the vogue for true crime podcasts, Denise Mina’s latest thriller is a whip-smart, blackly comic novel about a wronged wife and an unsolved yachting murder. Fiercely original and of-the-moment, Conviction cements Mina’s pre-eminent place in the crime writing firmament.
author: Denise Mina

title: If I Never Met You
description: When Laurie cooks up a fake romance with the office womaniser to get back at her ex, reality soon takes an unexpected turn in McFarlane’s polished romantic comedy. Brilliantly constructed and brimming with quotable one-liners, If I Never Met You delights on every page.
author: Mhairi McFarlane

title: Her Husband's Mistake: A marriage, a secret, and a wife's choice...
author: Sheila O'Flanagan

title: The Country Bride - The Village Secrets 3
description: From the bestselling author of historical romance, The Country Bride is a tale of heartbreak and hope, filled with feisty female characters to fall in love with. Heart-warming and gripping in equal measure, The Country Bride offers pure escapist pleasure.
author: Dilly Court

title: The Clockmaker's Daughter
description: Kate Morton’s sixth novel is an ambitious tale of deception and invention, bringing together multiple voices over 150 years through the mystery of the timeless figure of the clockmaker’s daughter.
author: Kate Morton

title: Things Fall Apart - Penguin Modern Classics
author: Chinua Achebe

title: Diary of a Somebody
description: Bilston’s terrific debut is that rare find: a genuinely funny – not to mention bittersweet and clever - comic novel. Interspersed with the hilarious, parodic poems that have made his name on Twitter, Diary of a Somebody follows the misadventures of the poet, sometime Casanova and expert procrastinator as he variously pursues love, fame and an unfortunately missing rival. A laugh-aloud pleasure.
author: Brian Bilston

title: Clock Dance
description: The deceptively effortless grace with which Anne Tyler weaves her quietly magnificent fiction leaves an indelible mark on Clock Dance. A story of regret, destiny and the path not taken is transformed from cliché to profundity by the clarity of Tyler’s psychological insight and the crispness of her prose.
author: Anne Tyler

title: Dissolution - The Shardlake series
description: Launching one of our favourite historical fiction series, Dissolution introduces Tudor lawyer Matthew Shardlake as he roots out murder in the marshes. Peerlessly researched and utterly compelling.
author: C. J. Sansom

title: Pride and Prejudice - The Penguin English Library
author: Jane Austen

title: The God of Small Things: Winner of the Booker Prize
description: A profound meditation on history and humanity in all its forms, The God of Small Things transformed Roy into a literary sensation and raised the bar for multi-layered prose writing at the close of the twentieth century. Rich in character, wit and wisdom, this is a very special novel from a unique voice.
author: Arundhati Roy

title: Lost Children Archive
description: Daring, brave and fiercely intelligent, Mexican-born novelist Luiselli’s dual narrative of two very different family journeys plays with form and contrast to highlight the fissures and fault lines of a deeply divided and unequal society. Drawn from her first-hand experiences helping child asylum seekers, Luiselli’s first novel in English fashions the American road story into something genuinely novel: a blistering catalogue of migration and exile. Blazing with eloquent indignation and dark satire, Lost Children Archive is a profoundly human story about major political themes.
author: Valeria Luiselli

title: Norse Mythology
description: The magician of storytelling metamorphosis brings a characteristic playfulness to this fresh and vibrant reincarnation the ice and fire tales of Valhalla.
author: Neil Gaiman

title: Catch-22
description: Explosive, subversive, wild and funny, Joseph Heller's bestselling novel is a hilarious and tragic satire on military madness, and the tale of one man's efforts to survive it. An absurdist condemnation of armed conflict and a rallying cry against the arbitrary authority of those in power, Catch 22 is one of the landmarks of twentieth-century fiction.
author: Joseph Heller

title: And Then There Were None: The World's Favourite Agatha Christie Book
author: Agatha Christie

title: A Clockwork Orange - Penguin Modern Classics
author: Anthony Burgess

title: The Grapes of Wrath - Penguin Modern Classics
author: John Steinbeck

title: Winter in Sokcho
description: Beautifully exploiting split identities and the confusions of nationalism, Dusapin’s pin-sharp dissection of the relationship between North and South Korea as seen through the eyes of a guesthouse receptionist and a French cartoonist is a constant joy. Nuanced in characterisation and nimble in tone, Winter in Sokcho stands at the forefront of the new Korean literature.
author: Elisa Shua Dusapin

title: Grief Is the Thing with Feathers
description: A highly innovative debut novel which playfully blends poetry and prose whilst examining grief, fatherhood, and the restorative powers of literature. Startlingly original and emotive, this brilliant novel heralded the arrival of one of the most exciting voices in contemporary literary fiction.
author: Max Porter

title: Melmoth
description: Following former Waterstones Book of the Year, The Essex Serpent, was always going to be a tall order but Sarah Perry succeeds gloriously with this bold and eerie recasting of Charles Maturin's gothic classic, Melmoth the Wanderer. As a silent, lonely figure with bleeding feet stalks the guilty and conscience-racked, Melmoth provides a chilling portrait of life poised between absolution and the darkness that calls.
author: Sarah Perry

title: The Power
description: An electrifying masterpiece of feminist speculative fiction which imagines a world dominated by female power. A disturbing, urgent, dystopian satire which holds a mirror to our own world: this is fiction at its brightest and most compelling.
author: Naomi Alderman

title: Kafka on the Shore
description: A runaway teen and an ageing cat whisperer collide in this fabulist extravaganza that showcases all of Murakami’s philosophical playfulness and surreal exuberance. Kafka on the Shore effortlessly siphons the legacy of magic realism into Murakami’s own hypnotically skewed version, leaving the reader enthralled and intoxicated by the novel’s close.
author: Haruki Murakami

title: Life After Life
description: This kaleidoscopic novel, which considers the many different paths one life can take, paints a portrait of the 20th Century like no other. An incredible feat of storytelling and imagination by an author at the top of her game.
author: Kate Atkinson

title: If Beale Street Could Talk - Penguin Modern Classics
author: James Baldwin

title: The Wall
description: Framed against the aftermath of a catastrophic climate disaster known as ‘the Change’, Lanchester paints a deeply compelling picture of a divided nation, committed to defending its walls at all costs. The dark heir of his state-of-the-nation novel Capital, The Wall is a Middle England dystopia for our fractured and uncertain times. A thrillingly apposite allegory of Broken Britain that asks key questions about the choice between personal freedom and national interest.
author: John Lanchester

title: The Strawberry Thief
description: Borne in on a breeze of magic, mystery and (of course) chocolate, Joanne Harris ends a seven-year break from her Chocolat series as new eddies stir the sleepy village of Lansquenet-sous-Tannes as Viannne Rocher returns. As new rivalries emerge, conflict threatens to erupt into violence, and even murder in a novel that’s both a treat for fans and an ideal doorway for new readers.
author: Joanne Harris

title: The Master and Margarita
description: Shrewd, enchanting and extremely funny, Bulgakov’s seminal masterpiece is one of the most sparkling critiques of totalitarianism ever produced. Ingeniously intertwining narratives, from remorse-ridden Pontius Pilate to a persecuted writer in Stalinist Moscow, The Master and Margarita is a powerful meditation on love, evil, freedom and the greatest magician of all – literature.
author: Mikhail Bulgakov

title: The Periodic Table - Penguin Modern Classics
author: Primo Levi

title: I Owe You One
description: After her hit bestseller Surprise Me, Sophie Kinsella is back with a perfect spring pick me up about family, independence and the chain reaction that follows  a simple act of altruism. Kinsella excels in writing recognisable, likeable characters and her new heroine Fixie is no exception. A breezy romance, written with plenty of humour and charm.
author: Sophie Kinsella

title: The Last Kingdom - The Last Kingdom Series 1
author: Bernard Cornwell

title: Love is Blind
description: The author of Any Human Heart returns with a story of dangerous risk, obsessive passion and fatal ambition. A spry turn-of-the-century epic that manages to be both expansive and intimate.
author: William Boyd

title: The Kite Runner
description: An utterly absorbing and emotionally devastating account of betrayal and redemption amidst the turbulence of Afghanistan, Hosseini’s intensely powerful novel revolves around Amir and his attempts to right a grievous wrong from his past. Lyrical, evocative and immensely moving, The Kite Runner has rightly become a modern classic.
author: Khaled Hosseini

title: The Order of the Day
description: Emerging in its British translation at a moment of political turmoil with uncanny parallels to those it describes, Eric Vuillard’s Prix Goncourt-winning novel arrives on a wave of European critical acclaim. Told in staccato bursts and combining expertly researched real events with precisely imagined detail, it provides a unique and disconcerting perspective both on those who spearheaded Germany’s grim descent into war and on the fresh resonance of those moments today.
author: Eric Vuillard

title: In Cold Blood - Penguin Modern Classics
description: Often described as the first ‘Non-Fiction novel’, Truman Capote’s infamous account of the appalling murder of a Kansas family which shocked America in the ‘50s is also a classic of the true crime genre, a fastidious piece of investigative journalism, and a pitiless investigation into the motives of evil.
author: Truman Capote
